page.title: 16Peat in Evie
page.content: Peat is made up of vegetable matter which has died and rotted. It contains carbon which makes it burn easily. Most peat banks were given by the landowners to their tenants to keep them in fuel. A{ritting knife}is used to open up a bank and take off the top turf, while a{tusker}is the tool for cutting up the peat. Whole families visit the peat banks in May to spread peats for drying. The peats are then raised for further drying, rued (gathered into heaps) or dyked. In July the peats are taken home for stacking. 5 to 7 tonnes are required for a year's supply of domestic fuel. Commercial vehicles are now moving in to some areas but in Evie traditional methods are still used. Most people still burn peat for fuel.
